Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Failure Prediction and Reliability Analysis of Ultra-High Strength Steel Autobody Manufacturing Systems by Utilizing Material Microstructure Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to use structural information of system components to improve prediction of reliability and failure in complex systems. The results of this project are expected to be of great benefit to the auto industry. In particular, improved reliability and failure prediction of manufacturing tooling systems will lead to more efficient and effective maintenance planning and reductions in tool failures. This, in turn, will lead to improvements in product quality and reduction in cost. Lab-enhancement and on-site studies will provide real-world experience and problem-solving skills for engineering education.

This research project deals with efficiently extracting material micro-structure characteristics and incorporating them into system reliability models to improve the accuracy of failure and reliability prediction. The new methodology will be applied, as an example, to the autobody manufacturing system of ultra-high strength steels, which is currently of great interest to the automotive industry but faces challenges in failure prediction and reliability analysis of manufacturing tool systems. Statistical methods will be developed to analyze and extract the micro-structure statistical characteristics and features of workpiece and tool materials that determine the strength competition and tool damage processes. In addition, a physical-statistical model that incorporates the extracted micro-structural features will be developed to describe the tool degradation process. Based on these, a reliability model of the repairable multi-component manufacturing tool system will be obtained. The research results will be implemented and validated through a three-stage process, including lab tests at the university lab, experiment and model validation using industry tryout, and validation and implementation in real manufacturing processes.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF GOALI project has developed a generic methodology to extract material microstructure information efficiently, and incorporate it to enable accurate failure prediction and reliability analysis. The methods are applied, as an example, to the auto body manufacturing system of ultra-high strength steels (UHSS), which is currently of great interest in the automotive industry but facing enormous challenges in failure prediction and reliability analysis of manufacturing tool systems. The project generated a significant amount of valuable data including (1) multiple UHSS microstructure, mechanical and material properties data, (2) material damage failure time and evolution data, and (3) manufacturing system failure and maintenance data. The data is collected from the PIs’ Material Process and Manufacturing (MPM) lab at Wayne state university, an industry tryout under US Auto Steel Partnership (A/SP) Tooling Optimization subcommittee, and a manufacturing production line of industrial collaborator.

The project developed novel statistical models, reliability methods, and optimal fault management from material microstructure to multi-component manufacturing systems at three scales: (1) At the microscopic level, new statistical methods were developed to efficiently analyze and extract microstructure features and information from the complex material microstructure images. (2) At the component level, novel reliability models are proposed for reliability analysis by incorporating the extracted material microstructure information. The results show that a significant improvement is achieved for material failure prediction compared with the existing methods. (3) At the system level, reliability analysis and optimal maintenance policies were proposed to capture failure dependencies of multiple components for repairable manufacturing systems under general repair actions. The developed methods can achieve much more accurate failure prediction and significant reduction of maintenance costs.

The research results are validated and implemented through a well-planned three-stage process including lab test and validation at Wayne State University (WSU), experiment and model validation using industry tryout, and validation and implementation in real manufacturing processes at Chrysler Corporation.

The participating students have been trained in multi-disciplinary fields of applied statistics, mechanical engineering, materials science, and reliability engineering. New courses/lab sections have been developed for undergraduate and graduate curricula. Research accomplishments were honored three best paper/finalist awards, disseminated at top IE/ME journals and international/national conferences, and imparted at local workshops to industry engineers and operators.

 


Last Modified: 08/21/2018
Modified by: Qingyu Yang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF GOALI project has developed a generic methodology to extract material microstructure information efficiently, and incorporate it to enable accurate failure prediction and reliability analysis. The methods are applied, as an example, to the auto body manufacturing system of ultra-high strength steels (UHSS), which is currently of great interest in the automotive industry but facing enormous challenges in failure prediction and reliability analysis of manufacturing tool systems. The project generated a significant amount of valuable data including (1) multiple UHSS microstructure, mechanical and material properties data, (2) material damage failure time and evolution data, and (3) manufacturing system failure and maintenance data. The data is collected from the PIs? Material Process and Manufacturing (MPM) lab at Wayne state university, an industry tryout under US Auto Steel Partnership (A/SP) Tooling Optimization subcommittee, and a manufacturing production line of industrial collaborator. The project developed novel statistical models, reliability methods, and optimal fault management from material microstructure to multi-component manufacturing systems at three scales: (1) At the microscopic level, new statistical methods were developed to efficiently analyze and extract microstructure features and information from the complex material microstructure images. (2) At the component level, novel reliability models are proposed for reliability analysis by incorporating the extracted material microstructure information. The results show that a significant improvement is achieved for material failure prediction compared with the existing methods. (3) At the system level, reliability analysis and optimal maintenance policies were proposed to capture failure dependencies of multiple components for repairable manufacturing systems under general repair actions. The developed methods can achieve much more accurate failure prediction and significant reduction of maintenance costs. The research results are validated and implemented through a well-planned three-stage process including lab test and validation at Wayne State University (WSU), experiment and model validation using industry tryout, and validation and implementation in real manufacturing processes at Chrysler Corporation. The participating students have been trained in multi-disciplinary fields of applied statistics, mechanical engineering, materials science, and reliability engineering. New courses/lab sections have been developed for undergraduate and graduate curricula. Research accomplishments were honored three best paper/finalist awards, disseminated at top IE/ME journals and international/national conferences, and imparted at local workshops to industry engineers and operators.
